required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Elastic Stable Intramedullary Nailing of Dislocated Clavicle Fractures in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Elastic Stable Intramedullary Nailing of Dislocated Clavicle Fractures in Children and Adolescents: Lessons Learned From the First 20 Patients

brief_summary.textblock:
Most Clavicular Fractures in Children can be Treated Conservatively. Our Own Study showed a Benefit towards Much Lower Pain and Better Cosmesis in Adolescents when Treated with Elastic Stable Intramedullary Nailing.
The First 20 Patients Treated with this Method will be examined for Functional (CONSTANT and MURLEY-Score) and Cosmetic Results as well as Ultrasound-Morphology of both clavicles and Patients`satisfaction (CSS-8). Further on, all complications and problems will be documented.

clinical_study.condition: Dislocated Clavicular Fracture Treated With Elastic Stable Intramedullary Nailing

study_pop.textblock: Last 24 Patients we Treated with ESIN

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Only Dislocated Shaft Fractures or Pseudarthrosis after Conservative Treatment of Dislocated CSF in Children and Adolescents Treated with Elastic Stable Intramedullary Nailing
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age > 17 years
- Pathologic fractures
- Lateral or Medial Fractures of the Clavicle

facility.name: Department of Pediatric Surgery University Hospital

reference.citation: Prinz KS, Rapp M, Kraus R, Wessel LM, Kaiser MM. [Dislocated midclavicular fractures in children and adolescents: who benefits from operative treatment?]. Z Orthop Unfall. 2010 Jan;148(1):60-5. doi: 10.1055/s-0029-1186155. Epub 2009 Oct 19. German.

results_reference.citation: Rapp M, Prinz K, Kaiser MM. Elastic stable intramedullary nailing for displaced pediatric clavicle midshaft fractures: a prospective study of the results and patient satisfaction in 24 children and adolescents aged 10 to 15 years. J Pediatr Orthop. 2013 Sep;33(6):608-13. doi: 10.1097/BPO.0b013e31829d1a76.
